home.text: There is a housing crisis in Groningen! Lots of international students are coming here to study, but find they have nowhere to stay. The university is not taking enough precautions so we all together have to find a solution. This is why we have started a couch surfing initiative. These are people from Groningen helping homeless students out of solidarity.

whoAreWe.title: Who are we?
whoAreWe.text: SOS Shelter our students is a campaign organized by a coalition of different student groups, who are concerned about the housing situation in Groningen. The groups involved are Democratische Academie Groningen, Groningen Feminist Network, Groninger Studentenbond, Internationale Socialisten, Lijst Calimero, and ROOD Groningen.

theProblem.title: What is the problem?
theProblem.text: We got together because we anticipate that there will be a huge housing crisis at the beginning of the academic year. An estimated 1300 more students than last year will join the university, and students who stayed elsewhere last year because of online education now have to return. Despite this, the university is only providing 195 beds in emergency housing. We have been asking for months for this to be increased, but the university is not listening. We expect that at the beginning of this academic year there will be students homeless in Groningen.

toDo.title: What are we going to do?
toDo.text: Everyone deserves a roof over their head. Therefore we continue campaigning for enough emergency housing now, as well as structural solutions to the housing problem in Groningen. Next to this, we are organizing a couch surfing action. People needing a temporary house can stay for a few days or longer with someone else. For example, maybe in the bedroom of a child that left for university in another town, on the couch in your student house, or on an air mattress in your living room.

stories.title: Stories of SOS: Episode 1
text: Our conversation was almost over when Imran looked straight at me, and for one sentence spoke with the surprising clarity and determination of someone who has no other choice but to make their suffering so explicit that others just won’t be able not to understand them: “ I never faced such a difficult situation in my life “ he told me in a politely quiet but firm tone, “ We just don’t know where to go “. Imrad came to Groningen with his friend Rasel from a small Asian country to pursue a technical degree at the University, as they both thought that a dutch degree would provide them with more opportunities than one from their home country.

A degree that will cost them at least 13600€/year, coming from a nation with an average salary of less than 200€ per month. Instead of being able to fully focus on this expensive investment, they are facing homelessnes, in a city they don’t know, in a country whose language they don’t speak and in a culture that is unfamiliar to them. A place which lies more than 7000 kilometers away from their home, with institutions and rules that are foreign to them, without having any friends or family here where they could seek shelter. Their reservation in their hotel will run out by the time of writing, Sunday the 05th, and Imran told me that they were not able to find anything else yet. He doesn’t know what to do anymore.

When I asked Imran where he sees the root of the problem, he made it very clear that it was irresponsible of the University to admit way more students than its city could sustain. Additionally, before coming here, it was not communicated to him at all by his school how dire this situation is and how difficult the search would be. They stated that they hope to find something next week, but even though both seemed like very polite, respectful and friendly persons this seems very unlikely given the circumstances.
stories.disclaimer: *All personal data, including their original pictures, were anonymized as they both fear repercussions by their University.

statement.title: Statement

text.preface: Shelter Our Students (SOS) has organized a couchsurfing platform to temporarily house homeless students in Groningen. The situation in Groningen is untenable. In this statement, we declare our understanding of what caused the situation as it is now, and our demands for change. This statement is directed at the Rijksuniversiteit Groningen and the municipality of Groningen. If you support our demands, please demonstrate this by signing the form linked below and sharing it with others. Both organizations and individuals are encouraged to sign.

list.title: 1. The current situation in Groningen
text: At the beginning of this academic year in Groningen, over 600 students signed up for the emergency couchsurfing platform set up to host students who are unable to find housing in the city. We, Shelter Our Students, set up this platform because we predicted that many more students would arrive in the city than last year. Year after year, international students end up homeless in emergency housing in September as they are unable to find a room before the start of their studies. They must pay to stay in large, cheerless dorms, or otherwise stay at a hostel as an expensive short-term last resort. But the hotels and hostels have filled up, as has the emergency housing, and there are not enough couchsurfing hosts to house all 600 students who signed up on our platform. Students are drawn into the University but upon arrival are left to sleep on the streets.

list.title: 2. The university’s responsibility
text: The Rijksuniversiteit Groningen does not adequately prepare the incoming international students for the reality of finding housing in Groningen - most claim to have been completely unaware and unprepared for how difficult it actually is. The University’s PR strategy, characterized by slogans as #happyinGroningen, is misleading at best and dangerous at worst. More importantly, the University sees students end up in these stressful circumstances every year and yet has not taken the steps necessary to prevent this situation from arising again. In 2018, student-led protests pressured the University to agree to four demands in order to improve the situation for students who were living in emergency tents and to speak out against the funding model that incentivizes the growth of universities.

Three years later, the situation is even worse than it was then, even though the University was warned months before the current crisis started about the inadequacy of this year’s planned emergency housing. The housing situation has not improved and the Rijksuniversiteit Groningen continues to draw in more (international) students than it can take.

list.title: 3. The broader problem
text: The logic of this crisis can be recognized throughout many different developments in the Netherlands. WOinActie has been protesting the financial model and underfinancing of the universities and shown us how the increasing numbers of students drive up the unpaid overwork of staff. The University must stop being run as a business according to the perverse, neoliberal profit incentives in order for the quality of life of students and teachers to improve. The Woonprotesten throughout the country this month show us that the system of housing that allows investors and slumlords (huisjesmelkers) free reign is not in the interest of buildings’ main aim: housing people. Housing is a fundamental human right, but housing prices sky-rocket and the right of residence is threatened by the landlord levy (verhuurderheffing) and vacant houses bought by foreign investors. In both cases, profits are valued above the quality of people’s lives and work. Rising tuition, housing prices and the student loan system (leenstelsel) make housing and education increasingly a privilege of the wealthy, rather than a right. These ever-deteriorating living conditions cannot be seen separately from the capitalist system of private property and the neoliberal drive towards privatization that exacerbates them.

list.title: 4. Our perspective and demands
text: Understanding this, the university board will claim that it is not in their power to change the reality of housing in Groningen. However, the actions the board takes, but especially the actions it does not take, do not have the students’ interests at heart. In order for the structure within which the University functions to change, the University must speak and act against this very structure that causes their students harm. For this reason, we are left no choice but demand that the University complies with the following four demands to alleviate the student housing crisis in Groningen in the short term:
1. Immediate arrangement of free emergency housing for all homeless students in the city
2. Improvement of communication about housing to internationals - including about scammers
3. Building of 2000 rooms of student housing on Zernike Campus
4. Public commitment to limiting the number of students the RUG accepts and preparation of sufficient emergency housing in the upcoming years

In the longer term, we stand for the reorganization of the financing of universities in the Netherlands from businesses to institutions aimed at education. We also stand for the overhaul of the housing sector in the Netherlands, the increase of social housing and the expropriation of housing from investors and slumlords. In short, we stand for accessible and fair housing for all and humane higher education for students and teachers. We demand that the University and municipality proclaim their support of the interests of the people and do what is in their power to change the system that produced this crisis.

items.a: You can send us an email at shelterourstudents@gmail.com with any questions you might have. If you would prefer to talk to one of our team members over the phone, you can leave your phone number in your email and we will call you as soon as we are available.

You can always help us by joining the initiative! We are calling and matching students with hosts and organizing actions all the time, and we can use all the help we can get. If you feel like helping out as well, then please consider signing up

items.q: How can I keep up to date with SOS?
items.a: You can join our update Whatsapp group. In this group, only the admins can send messages so you will not receive spam, but only occasional updates from us. You can join through this link: https://chat.whatsapp.com/Io6p49rgWJg2vNj41VMMiy . You can also follow our instagram at @

items.q: Is Shelter Our Students liable for any damages?
items.a: No, hosting someone is at your own risk. However, if you would like us to place them somewhere else, we can do that. You are not obliged to host anyone longer than you want. We also do not do dispute resolution.

items.q: Is it possible to meet the student before inviting them to my house?
items.a: Yes, this is possible. We have a temporary office where you can get coffee with us and the student beforehand. If you would like to make use of this, just get in touch with us and we will see when the office is available.

No, we are a mutual aid program. You cannot charge rent through us. However, you can ask for a small compensation for costs you make by hosting them. You will need to arrange this with the student themself.

items.q: How long will I need to host someone?
items.a: We would like people to at least host someone for a week. How long you host someone stays with you, is entirely up to you. If you want them to leave earlier than expected that is completely understandable. We’ll try to find a new place for them. While staying with you the students will keep trying to find a permanent place and they will leave when they find something.

items.q: Do I need to be home all the time?
items.a: No, you don’t have to be home all the time. They can stay there without you. Most hosts give their student a spare key.

items.q: How does the matching process work?
items.a: We do not do background checks of the students. We only provide the basic information they provided to us. If you want to know more you can call or email them and ask them yourself. If you feel like it is not a good match, then we will try to find someone else for you.

items.q: Is it a problem if I live far away from the city?
items.a: No, this is not a problem. These students need to find a place, so there is no time to be picky. If you live in Haren or Leeuwarden for example, then this is not a problem. Just let us know, so the students are aware of this.

faq.title: FAQ for students looking for emergency housing

items.q: Can SOS provide me permanent housing?
items.a: No, we can't provide you with permanent housing. We can only match you with a local who can give you a temporary place to stay. This can be in the form of a spare couch or a spare room or even an air mattress on the ground.

items.q: Will I need to pay rent?
items.a: No, you will not need to pay if you find a place through us. We are a mutual aid program. However, some hosts will ask you to pay a small compensation for the costs they make by housing you.

items.q: Do I need to keep looking for a permanent place to stay?
items.a: Yes, this is a temporary place to stay. So when you have found a place you will go there and you will not stay with your host. You need to keep searching for a place to stay.

items.q: How does the matching process work?
items.a: We’ll call you to ask if you still need emergency housing. Then we will search for a host for you. After this we will give you contact details of the host and you can arrange a time and place to meet.

items.q: Can I get a place together with my partner/friend?
items.a: We will try to find a place for the both of you, but we can’t promise we will find anything. If we can’t find anything we will try to find seperate places for you.
